0156027321|5.0|What a charmer this story is!  We meet Pi a young Indian adolescent who is open to all the possibilities of heaven and earth and sea.  The story of this boy, a tiger and the two thirds of a year on a lonely life boat will make you cry, laugh and anticipate potential disasters from beginning to end of the tale.  Don't be deterred by the author's fairly long discussions of religion, philosphy and the rightness of zoos early on in the book.  Pi himself and his own lessons about life and spirituality will carry you through those early chapters.  The story is full of tantalizing twists and turns and an ending that is rich with imagination and reflection and humor.   <br />The style of writing is clear and straightforward.  The story moves the reader to explore the shades of gray in life, rather than the blacks and white that we often hold onto with such fervor when faced with experiences new to us.<br />Try it.  You will like it.  A lot!
B000092ZYX|5.0|Radiohead. Politics. I don't know what to say other than those couple of words. I could go on and on about how much I enjoy this album, and how much this band has inspired me and led me to believe that there is some future for the rock industry.<br />Some tend to think of this as 'going back' to previous recording and experimentation. Not at all. This band constantly amazes me with every minute of this album. Being in a band myself, I can't even comprehend the genius it takes to write such songs. Songs that can warm you heart or make you so frightfully paranoid. <br />I prefer not to go into a rundown of each song individually, but I would note that every song has superior craft and musicianship. I'm not trying to sound preachy, and I'm not trying to be hip by listeing to this band. But you can listen to this group 10 times and never really hear them. &quot;2+2=5&quot; is a masochistic prog rock song reminiscent of Orwell's &quot;1984&quot;. Other highlights include &quot;Sit down, stand up&quot;, &quot;Where I end and you begin&quot;, and the most experimental track on the disc &quot;Myxamatosis&quot;. The sounds of a diseased rabbit never felt so morbid.<br />I would, however, like to sing out one track in particular. &quot;A Wolf at the Door&quot;. Of all the tracks this album throws at you, it comes at you the fastest and with the most emotion. So incredibly melodic, but so very violent. &quot;Steal all the children, if I don't pay the ransom.&quot; If this album has a most brilliant moment, I feel it would be in this track.<br />I'm not sure if this album will stand the test of time, as OK Computer has (and it certainly isn't as good), but this band will most definately come to be the most recognizable band in the world. <br />For those of us who listen...
B0000AUHQT|2.0|Promoted heavily at the time of its release for its glamour and high style, &quot;The Great Gatsby&quot; is a surprisingly limp film with little of either. There's nothing outstanding about it which, given the money and talent that went into it, is a pretty damning comment. The Newport locations are wasted, and most of the actors come off little better. Ralph Lauren's fashions (highly touted prior to the film's release) don't seem especially special, and Douglas Slocombe's cinematography is disappointingly soft and low contrast. Indeed, the only real sign of the film's budget are the loving shots of expensive cars, clothing and crockery and the endless, over-crowded party scenes. Both give new definition to the word pointless.<br />At the peak of his career, Robert Redford is not bad, but does not seem very well cast and doesn't look that good. Mia Farrow, on the other hand, is too well cast as the flighty, self-indulgent Daisy of his dreams, managing to annoy much more than charm. Bruce Dern is grossly out of scale to the rest of the cast; his racist, brutal posturings seem to belong in another movie. Sam Waterston manages not to disgrace himself in the thankless role of the silent witness to other people's affairs. The only above average performance is by Scott Wilson as the mechanic, George, and even he could stand to have a beat or two trimmed from his suffering.<br />The biggest problem with the movie is its all too apparent effort to overwhelm. A much lighter approach, even an ironic one, would seem to suit the material more effectively. Heavy with the attempt to be atmospheric, it feels overstuffed and tentative. There is no sense that anyone behind or in front of the camera had a driving passion to put the story on the screen, or even bothered to ask why it was being made. It's a ponderous movie, witless and heavy-handed, over-produced and cheap at the same time.

B000002UDD|3.0|After the slow and building success of their previous album Peace Sells...But Who's Buying?, Megadeth went back into the studio and soon released So Far, So Good...So What! While the album is as heavy as their previous two albums, the songwriting appeared to be unfocused when compared to strong albums like Peace Sells... and Rust In Peace.<br />The album starts out promising with the sinister instrumental \\"Into The Lungs Of Hell\\" and the fast riffing of \\"Set The World Afire.\\" Other strong tracks include the excellent \\"In My Darkest Hour\\" and \\"Mary Jane.\\" The rest of the album has the heavy riffing but the songs don't stand out. \\"502\\" and the cover of the Sex Pistols' \\"Anarchy In The U.K.\\" are okay, but certainly not among their best material. The closing tracks \\"Liar\\" and \\"Hook In Mouth\\" are unmemorable and sound unfinished. The album as a whole has a rushed feel to it. Chief songwriter and guitarist Dave Mustaine was going through some personal problems at this time as well. But he would clean up and the band would release the excellent Rust In Peace in 1990. If you're a diehard fan, you already own this. Newcomers may want to check out Peace Sells... or Rust In Peace first.

B0000DD7LB|4.0|I am not the biggest fan of Britney's voice, and while I'm not going to divulge into the argument of whether or not she can sing, I can say that I do find some of her work very catchy and likeable. I Did it Again.&quot;<br />In Britney's fourth album, she matures in her song material a great deal.  She's starting to tread into more adult territory and is experiencing with different grooves other than the traditional bubble-gum pop she's stuck with through most of her career.  In all honesty, this album was quite a surprise to me.  It's much better than I anticipated.  She's trying to establish new ground and make a new image for herself besides the bopping teen idol she's been for most of her career.  While its arguable as to whether or not she accomplishes it with this album, she's definitely on her way.<br />1.  Me Against the Music -- The first single.  It's got a good beat to it and while I don't find the Madonna segments that necessary (probably something added in later to boost up the hype over tha MTV kiss), it's very catchy and easy to get hooked on.  A pretty good choice for the first single.<br />2.  (I Got That) Boom Boom -- If this isn't the second single I'll be a bit surprised.  It's got &quot;clubbing&quot; written all over it.  The Ying Yang twins provide nice backlining to her vocals.  A great tune to dance to.<br />3.  Showdown -- Funky beats, breathy vocals, and twisted guitar lines.  Far different in terms of what she's done so far, not just in terms of lyrical content, but it sounds a lot different.<br />4.  Breathe on Me -- Exactly what it says: Britney's voice in this one is heavily breathy and pant-like, but I rather like it.  The background music is very mysterious and heavily relied on beats, kinda reminds me of Kylie Minogue's music.  <br />5.  Early Mornin' -- I had to listen to this a few times to make sure it was Britney.  Her voice sounds a lot different in this one compared to the others.  Not great, but not bad.<br />6.  Toxic -- Screaming violins and guitar segments.  Probably the most recognizable in terms of the other tracks.  I like how Britney sounds on this one.  A very good track, it's both different and unique.<br />7.  Outrageous -- This is definitely another clubbing tune.  I find it impossible not to get hooked on the catchy rhythms of this one.  A very good addition to the CD.<br />8.  Touch of My Hand -- Don't really care for this one.  I give it props for it's very unorthdox lyrical content, but in terms of musical appeal and vocals, it doesn't do much for me.<br />9.  The Hook Up -- Very funky, but Britney's voice sounds so digital in some of the vocal segments that sometimes it's unrecognizable.  She kinda sounds like Missy Elliot at some points.  The background music actually sounds like something I'd expect in a rapping song.  <br />10.  Shadow -- Now this is a very pretty ballad.  I do agree with her many critics regarding this tune; her voice is not very strong, and it is evident here.  It's also lost a great deal of its former pureness and clarity from her earlier work, which is too bad.  Nonetheless, this ballad is very beautiful.<br />11.  Brave New Girl -- Probably the only track that is very reminiscint of her bubble gum pop days, as it is a track I would've expected to find on one of her earlier CDs.  Her voice is also highly digital here.  If you prefer her earlier style and don't mind the digital quality to her voice, you'll like this one.<br />12.  Everytime -- The final ballad.  I like her voice a lot better on this one than in &quot;Shadow,&quot; it sounds a lot purer and the piano complements her voice well.  A nice closing to the CD.<br />Overall, I enjoyed this CD.  Yeah, there were a few that I could've done without, but hey, every CD has their misses.  If you are looking for Britney to continue her traditional poppy tunes, you won't like this CD.  If you enjoy R&amp;B and hip hop-like beats, give this a try.  I give Britney props for trying something new, and she doesn't do that bad at it.  So give it a chance... you might like it.

The dance/sex scene was too long and irrelevant to the story.  It would have OK if it were to add some amusment to the movie, but it didn't.  The special effects were OK.  I thought the first one did a better job.  There, they'd slow something down in mid sequence, but here they'd slow down the whole scene.  I think they should have paid more attention to writing story than trying to out do the previous movies fashion and special effects statements.

0156029065|3.0|This book is the life story of Baudolino as told by the title character. It should be noted that Baudolino is a great story teller and a known liar. As Eco ties in many historical and fantasy figures into Baudolino's life the reader is never sure what is the truth and what is not. As a whole the story was great. Having never read one of Eco's books before I was not sure what I was getting into. I found parts of the story a struggle to get through. However, the book was worth sticking to and the ending was very good. If you are a fan of Eco's books you will enjoy this story. If you have never read one of Eco's book I do not think I would recommend this as a first taste.
